Leader.name: Omar Barziani
Leader.description: A former leader in the IMK, Barziani left the group in 1997 with Hassan Sofi and joined Sofi’s new organization, Kurdish Hamas. Following Sofi’s assassination in 1998, Barziani became the leader of Kurdish Hamas.
Leader.source: Romano, David. “An Outline of Kurdish Islamist Groups in Iraq.” The Jamestown Foundation, September 2007. Web. 27 July 2015.

NameChange.name: Islamic Movement in Kurdistan (IMK)
NameChange.description: The Islamic Movement of Kurdistan (IMK) (also known as the Islamic Movement in Iraqi Kurdistan (IMIK)): The Islamic Movement of Kurdistan was the group’s formal name when established in 1987. The group has retained this name even as portions of its membership have broken off to form other more radical Islamist groups. {{Romano, David. “An Outline of Kurdish Islamist Groups in Iraq.” The Jamestown Foundation, September 2007. Web. 27 July 2015.}} {{“Profile: Kurdish Islamist movement.” BBC News, 13 Jan. 2003. Web. 27 July 2015.}} {{“Prominent Iraqi Islamic Groups.” Islamopedia, Date unknown. Web. July 28 2015.}}

NameChange.name: Islamic Unity Movement of Kurdistan (IUMK) (Also known as the Islamic Federation of Kurdistan)
NameChange.description: In 1999 the IMK merged with Kurdish Hamas and al-Nahda to form the Islamic Federation of Kurdistan. However the union did not last long and the group split back up in 2001. {{Kakei, Saed. “The Islamic Movement of Kurdistan: From conflict to cooperation.” EKurd Daily, 25 March 2013. Web. 28 July 2015.}} {{Romano, David. “An Outline of Kurdish Islamist Groups in Iraq.” The Jamestown Foundation, September 2007. Web. 27 July 2015.}}

NameChange.name: Islamic Movement in Kurdistan.
NameChange.description: After the fragmentation of the Islamic Federation of Kurdistan, the IMK readopted its original name. {{Kakei, Saed. “The Islamic Movement of Kurdistan: From conflict to cooperation.” EKurd Daily, 25 March 2013. Web. 28 July 2015.}} {{Romano, David. “An Outline of Kurdish Islamist Groups in Iraq.” The Jamestown Foundation, September 2007. Web. 27 July 2015.}}

Group.name: The Kurdistan Islamic Group
Group.description: The Kurdistan Islamic Group, also simply called the Islamic Group, was a splinter group of the Islamic Unity Movement of Kurdistan (IUMK) that was formed by Ali Bapir in 2001. The KIG is considered far more radical in its Wahabi ideology than the Islamic Movement of Iraq (IMK ) and seeks to establish Shariah Law throughout Iraq. Although he group, however, defines itself as a non-violent Salafi movement, it has clashed violently with Ansar al-Islam in the areas surrounding its headquarters in Khormal. The KIG is a recognized political party in Iraq and is currently one of the two largest Kurdish Islamist parties in the country. In the 2005 Iraqi parliamentary elections, the KIG won 2 seats in the National Assembly, simultaneously winning 6 seats in the in the Iraqi Kurdistan legislative elections that took place on the same day. In the 2009 Iraqi Kurdistan legislative elections, the group joined the Service and Reform List coalition, which came in third in the election, winning 13 seats out of 111. Subsequently, the KIG won two seats in the 2010 Iraqi parliamentary elections, 6 seats in the 2013 Iraqi Kurdistan legislative elections and three seats in the 2014 Iraqi parliamentary election.

Group.name: Al Qaeda Kurdish Battalions
Group.description: Al Qaeda Kurdish Battalions (AQKB) is a Kurdish, Salafi militant organization affiliated with Al Qaeda (AQ) that operates in Iraqi Kurdistan. Since its formation in March 2007, the group has a primarily targeted the Kurdistan Regional Government. However, beginning in April 2014, AQKB may also be engaged fighting the Islamic State (IS).

Attack.description: AQKB militants claimed responsibility for a car bomb that was detonated at the Kurdistan Interior and Security Ministries building, killing 19 civilians.
Attack.source: "US Names al Qaeda-linked Outfit as Terrorist Entity." DaijiWorld, 6 January 2012. Web. 27 July 27, 2012.

Attack.description: Several AQKB militants were arrested after the Kurdish security forces foiled an AQKB suicide bomb attack in Sulaymaniyah, Iraq.
Attack.source: "US Names al Qaeda-linked Outfit as Terrorist Entity." DaijiWorld, 6 January 2012. Web. 27 July 27, 2012.

Attack.description: AQKB operatives ambushed and killed seven border guards and another security force member in Penjwin, Iraq.
Attack.source: "US brands al-Qaeda Kurdish Battalions 'terrorist'." Reuters, Date unknown. Web. 27 July 2012.

Leader.name: Abdallah Hassan al-Surani
Leader.description: Surani has released public statements of behalf of AQKB and is believed to be the group’s official spokesman.
Leader.source: Khalil, Lydia. “The Kurdish Brigades: Al-Qaeda’s Kurdish Henchmen.” The Jamestown Foundation, Terrorism Focus 4(14), 18 May 2007. Web. 24 Aug. 2015.

Leader.name: Dilshad Kalari
Leader.description: Very little is known about Kalari although some sources believe him to be the operational leader of AQKB.
Leader.source: Khalil, Lydia. “The Kurdish Brigades: Al-Qaeda’s Kurdish Henchmen.” The Jamestown Foundation, Terrorism Focus 4(14), 18 May 2007. Web. 24 Aug. 2015.

Size.size: AQBK is thought to be relatively weak and small in
Size.citation: “US Designates Kurdish Group Terrorists.” Rudaw, 15 Jan. 2012. Web. 24 Aug. 2015.

Group.name: Kurdish Hamas
Group.description: Kurdish Hamas was a Kurdish Salafi organization formed by a group of veterans of the Afghanistan War who split from the Islamic Movement of Kurdistan (IMK) in 1997. Kurdish Hamas’ members tended to be more radical and Jihadist than those of the IMK as witnessed by its goal of implementing of Shariah Law across Iraq. The group was based in the city of Khormal and was known for its attacks on bookstores, clubs, beauty salons and tourist areas as well as for targeting women whom the group felt did not dress modestly enough. Kurdish Hamas was initially led by Hassan Sofi and subsequently by Omar Barziani after the IMK assassinated Sofi in 1998. In 1999, Kurdish Hamas merged with the IMK and al-Nahda to form the Islamic Unity Movement of Kurdistan (IUMK). The IUMK only lasted until 2001 at which point Barziani again split from the group with a large number of the IUMK’s more radical Islamist members. He temporarily reformed Kurdish Hamas, only to merge it with Tawheed in July 2001 to form the Tawheed Islamic Front (TIF), which itself eventually merged with several other Kurdish Islamist groups in order to form Ansar al-Islam in late 2001.

Group.name: Al-Nahda
Group.description: Al-Nahda (the Islamic Renaissance Movement) was founded in 1993 by Sadiq Abdul Aziz, brother of Islamic Movement of Kurdistan (IMK) leaders Uthman and Ali Abdul Aziz. Like his brother Uthman, Sadiq Abdul Aziz was an active member of the Muslim Brotherhood and Union of Muslim Scholars of Kurdistan throughout the 1980s. However, unlike Uthman, Sadiq Abdul Aziz maintained close ties between his organization and the Brotherhood throughout the 1990s. Furthermore, he focused al-Nahda on Islamic activism and education rather than on the political and militant activities pursued by Uthman Abdul Aziz and the IMK. In 1999 Sadiq and Ali Abdul Aziz, who succeeded Uthman as the leader of the IMK, merged their two organizations with Omar Barziani’s Kurdish Hamas to form the Islamic Unity Movement of Kurdistan (IUMK). The IUMK union only lasted until 2001, when it fragmented into several splinter groups. Although Sadiq and Ali reformed the IMK, many of the former al-Nahda members joined Ali Bapir’s new organization, the Kurdistan Islamic Group.

Group.name: The Islamic Unity Movement of Kurdistan
Group.description: The Islamic Unity Movement of Kurdistan (IUMK) was a Kurdish Islamist organization formed in 1999 by the merger of the Islamic Movement of Kurdistan (IMK), al-Nahda, and Kurdish Hamas. Very little is known about the IUMK, other than that it carried out a number of terrorist attacks against PUK and KDP strongholds throughout Iraqi Kurdistan. The group fell apart in 2001 when a large number of its members split off with Ali Bapir to form the Kurdistan Islamic Group and with Mullah Krekar to form the Reformist Group. Ali Abdul Aziz subsequently reformed the IMK with the remaining members of the IUMK.

Group.name: Tawhid
Group.description: Tawhid was a radical Kurdish Islamist militant organization led by Abdul Ghani Bazazi, who is thought to have formed the group in the summer of 2000. The group was based in Erbil and fiercely opposed the Kurdish Democratic Party (KDP). Tawhid’s most notable attacks was the assassination of the KDP’s Christian governor of Erbil, Frasno Hariri, in February 2001. Additionally, the group claimed responsibility for a string of smaller attacks in Iraqi Kurdistan in 2000 and 2001 that targeted non-Muslims, foreigners, and women deemed not to be dressed modestly enough. Many Tawhid militants were sheltered by the Islamic Movement of Kurdistan (IMK) in Halabjah when fleeing retaliation from the KDP. In July 2001, Tawhid joined with Kurdish Hamas to form the Tawhid Islamic Front (TIF), which later merged with several other groups to form Ansar al-Islam.

Group.name: Al-Tawhid Islamic Front
Group.description: In July 2001, two splinter groups of the Islamic Movement in Kurdistan, Kurdish Hamas and Tawhid, merged to formed Al-Tawhid Islamic Front (TIF). TIF was an independent group for three months in the summer of 2001and was credited with no major attacks. In September 2001, TIF merged with the Second Soran Unit to form Jund al-Islam

Leader.name: Abu Bakr al-Hawleri
Leader.description: Hawleri was previously a leader of Tawhid before the merger with Kurdish Hamas.
Leader.source: Romano, David. "An Outline of Kurdish Islamist Groups in Iraq." The Jamestown Foundation. September 2007. Retrieved on June 25, 2011, from http://www.scribd.com/doc/20777907/An-Outline-of-Kurdish-Islamist-Groups-in-Iraq

Group.name: Second Soran Unit
Group.description: The Second Soran Unit (SSU) was a predominantly Kurdish, Sunni Islamist militant group that was led by Asad Muhammad Hasan (more commonly known as Aso Hawleri). The SSU had been a military brigade in the Islamic Movement of Kurdistan (IMK) before splitting off to form an independent group in 1998. Then in 2001, the SSU merged with two other Kurdish Sunni groups to form Jund al-Islam, which shortly after became a founding member of Ansar al-Islam later that year.

Leader.name: Asad Muhammad Hasan
Leader.description: Hasan, better known as Aso Hawleri, was a veteran of the Afghanistan War against the Soviet Union and a member of the IMK from 1991-1998, who served on the IMK Central Council from 1997-1998 before breaking with the IMK to found the Second Soran Unit in 1998. After merging with Jund al-Islam and subsequently Ansar al-Islam in 2001, Hawleri was considered to be the 3rd ranking member in Ansar al-Islam and was believed to have been in command of the Second Soran Unit (then a brigade within Ansar al-Islam) when U.S. forces captured him in October 2003.
Leader.source: "Muslim Extremist Caught." LexisNexis Academic, The Daily Telegraph, 16 October 2003.}}

Size.citation: "Ansar al-Islam in Iraqi Kurdistan." Human Rights Watch, Date unknown. Web. 18 October 2010.

Group.name: Jund al-Islam
Group.description: Jund al-Islam was a Kurdish Islamist militant organization that was formed in September 2001 and was led by Abdullah Shafi. The group was formed by the merger of the Second Soran Unit and the Al-Tawhid Islamic Front (TIF), the latter of which was formed when Kurdish Hamas and Tawhid had merged in July 2001. The formation of Jund al-Islam was encouraged and financially supported by Al Qaeda’s Osama bin Laden. Additionally, at the group’s inception, roughly 60 of Jund al-Islam’s estimated 400 fighters were trained by Al-Qaeda operatives in Afghanistan. In Autumn 2001, Jund al-Islam clashed with the Islamic Movement of Kurdistan (IMK) and eventually wrested the Howraman region of Iraq from its control. Around the same time Jund al-Islam signed a ceasefire agreement with Ali Bapir’s Islamic group, after which the two organizations coordinated with one another. Later in 2001, Jund al-Islam joined with Mullah Krekar’s Reformist group to form Ansar al-Islam.

Group.name: The Reformist Group
Group.description: The Reformist Group was a Kurdish Islamist group that broke away from the Islamic Unity Movement of Kurdistan (IUMK) in early-mid 2001, under the leadership of Mullah Krekar. Krekar had previously been a member of the IMK and subsequently of Kurdish Hamas and the IUMK. Other than its Salafi Sunni ideology, little is known about the Reformist group as it was only in existence for a matter of months before merging with several other Arab and Kurdish Islamist groups to form Ansar al-Islam. Krekar was appointed head of this new organization.

Group.name: Ansar al-Islam Syria
Group.description: Following the advent of the civil war in Syria in 2011, Ansar al-Islam (AI) established a branch in Syria, which initially operated under the alias of Ansar al-Sham. This branch worked closely with AI’s allies in the region, namely Jabhat al-Nusra and Al Qaeda. By 2014, AI had publicly acknowledged Ansar al-Sham as a branch of its organization and the group became known simply as Ansar al-Islam Syria (AI Syria). Then on August 29, 2014, AI officially merged with the Islamic State (IS). However, AI Syria rejected the merger and has continued to operate under the name of Ansar al-Islam. The group is currently believed to be cooperating with Jabhat al-Nusra and Al Qaeda against the Assad Regime and IS. Most recently, in February 2016, the group was reported to be fighting against forces of the Kurdistan Workers’ Party (PKK) and the Jaysh al-Thuwar, a coalition of several former Free Syrian Army units, in the Ashrafiyeh neighborhood of Aleppo.

Group.name: Ansar al-Islam
Group.description: Ansar al-Islam (AI) is a predominantly Kurdish Salafist militant organization based in Iraqi Kurdistan. The group was formed in December 2001 by a merger of several other Kurdish Islamist groups. AI had ties with Al Qaeda and fought against secular Kurdish groups as well as the U.S.-led coalition and the Iraqi government. Since 2011, the group has also fought alongside Jabhat al-Nusra and the Islamic Front in Syria. Although it had previously opposed the Islamic State (IS), AI’s leadership announced that the group was disbanding and merging with IS in August 2014. However, the Syrian branch of AI rejected the merger and has continued to operate in Syria as Ansar al-Islam, occasionally clashing with IS as well as the Assad government and other insurgent groups.

Attack.description: In the spring of 2002, AI sent several gunmen to assassinate PUK leader, Barha, Salih. Salih survived the attack but five of his bodyguards were killed along with two of the AI assailants.
Attack.source: Schanzer, Jonathan. “Ansar al-Islam: Iraq’s al-Qaeda Connection.” The Washington Institute, 15 January 2003. Web. 24 Aug 2015.

Attack.description: AI claimed responsibility for bombing the Turkish Embassy in Baghdad.
Attack.source: Hider, James. "Suicide Bomb Hits Turkish Embassy." LexisNexis Academic, The Times, 15 October 2003.

Attack.description: The group carried out simultaneous suicide attacks at the headquarters of the KDP and the PUK in Erbil.
Attack.source: "Hawlati Reveals the Secret of Arbil Explosions." LexisNexis Academic, Hawlati via BBC Summary of World Broadcast, 11 February 2004.

Attack.description: AI perpetrated a series of attacks in the Diyala province including the assassination of an Iraqi policeman, a bombing which killed two Christian soldiers, and an attack on a Mahdi Army checkpoint that resulted in 6 deaths.
Attack.source: “Background Information on Ansar al-Islam.” Parliament of Australia, Date unknown. Web. 19 Aug 2015.

Attack.description: AI used a suicide bomber to attack a U.S. military dining facility at Marez in Mosul.
Attack.source: "Jaish Ansar al-Sunna." GlobalSecurity.org, 27 April 2005. Web. 5 February 2010.

Attack.description: AI claimed credit for the assassination of Sheikh Mahmoud Finjan, who was a senior assistant to the prominent Iraqi Shiite cleric, Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani.
Attack.source: Gregory, Kathryn. “Ansar al-Islam (Iraq, Islamists/Kurdish Separatists), Ansar al-Sunnah.” The Council on Foreign Relations, 5 Nov. 2008. Web. 30 June 2014.

Attack.description: In Ninawa, AI stopped a bus and took all the Yazidi passengers aboard prisoner. Though the other passengers were allowed to continue on their journey, AI took the Yazidi passengers to Mosul, where they were systematically executed.
Attack.source: "2007 Report on Terrorism." National Counterterrorism Center, 30 April 2008.

Attack.description: AI claimed credit for a suicide attack in Erbil outside the Kurdish Interior Ministry.
Attack.source: "Ansar al-Islam." Australian Parliament, 20 March 2009. Web. 5 February 2010.

Attack.description: Ansar al Islam, Jabhat al-Nusra, and the Islamic Front fought together near Aleppo to capture Jabal Shwayhana and Kafr Hamra from the Assad Regime.
Attack.source: al-Tamimi, Aymenn Jawad. “Key Updates on Iraq’s Sunni Insurgent Groups.” Brown Moses, 11 May 2014. Web. 20 Aug. 2015.

Attack.description: AI claimed responsibility for the suicide bombing of a Shiite militia camp in the town of Rabia, Iraq. In a statement released shortly after the attack, AI not only claimed that the Shiite militants had been about to deploy to Syria to assist the Assad regime, but that the Islamic State in Iraq (ISI), the successor of AQI and predecessor to IS, had participated in the operation.
Attack.source: Joscelyn, Thomas. “Ansar al Islam claims attacks against Iraqi military, police.” The Long War Journal, 20 June 2014. Web. 20 Aug 2015.

Attack.description: AI allegedly beheaded a PKK fighter it captured in Syria.
Attack.source: al-Tamimi, Aymenn Jawad. “Key Updates on Iraq’s Sunni Insurgent Groups.” Brown Moses, 11 May 2014. Web. 20 Aug. 2015.

Attack.description: An AI spokesman confirmed Iraqi press reports that AI was engaged fighting IS in the al-Rashad area of the Kirkuk province.
Attack.source: al-Tamimi, Aymenn Jawad. “Key Updates on Iraq’s Sunni Insurgent Groups.” Brown Moses, 11 May 2014. Web. 20 Aug. 2015.

Leader.name: Mullah Krekar
Leader.description: Mullah Krekar was a member of the Islamic Movement of Kurdistan (IMK) and subsequently the leader of the Reformist Group, a splinter of the IMK, before becoming the first Emir of AI in December 2001. After the U.S. invasion and offensive against AI in 2003, Krekar fled to Norway where he remains in exile. He is not believed to still be active in AI.
Leader.source: Al-Shafi'I, Muhammad. "Iraq: Ansar al-Islam Dismisses Krekar as Leader." LexisNexis Academic, Al-Sharq al-Aswat via BBC Summary of World Broadcasts, 23 August 2003.

Leader.name: Abdullah al-Shafii
Leader.description: Shafii replaced Krekar as the Emir of AI upon Krekar exile to Norway in 2003. Shafii was arrested by Iraqi security forces on May 3, 2010, and remains in custody.
Leader.source:
Roggio, Bill. "Iraqi Forces Arrest Leader of Ansar al Islam." The Long War Journal, 4 May 2010. Web. 27 July 2010. 
Gregory, Kathryn. “Ansar al-Islam (Iraq, Islamists/Kurdish Separatists), Ansar al-Sunnah.” The Council on Foreign Relations, 5 Nov. 2008.

Leader.name: Sheikh Abu Hashim Muhammad bin Abdul Rahman al Ibrahim
Leader.description: Ibrahim was announced as new Emir of Ansar al-Islam on December 5, 2011.
Leader.source: Joscelyn, Thomas and Bill Roggio. "Ansar al Islam names new Leader." The Long War Journal, 5 January 2012. Web. 3 August 2012.

Leader.name: Abu Ahmad
Leader.description: Ahmad was a senior leader in AI’s Iraqi branch. He was killed by Islamic State (IS) forces in 2014.
Leader.source: Al-Tamimi, Aymenn Jawad. “Jamaat Ansar al-Islam: Eulogy to Abu Ahmad of Mosul: Translation and Analysis.” Rubin Center, 15 April 2015. Web. 19 Aug. 2015.

NameChange.name: Ansar al-Islam
NameChange.description: Ansar al-Islam is the original name of the group. The group formally adopted this name in December 2001 after the merger of Jund al-Islam, the Reformist Group, and other Kurdish Islamist groups. {{Lia, Brynjar, "Ansar al-Islam Group Revisited," (Working Paper), Norwegian Defence Research Establishment, June 16, 2006, retrieved on February 5, 2010.}} {{Romano, David. “An Outline of Kurdish Islamist Groups in Iraq.” The Jamestown Foundation, September 2007. Web. 27 July 2015.}}

NameChange.name: Ansar al-Sunna
NameChange.description: Members of AI who were exiled to Iran following the U.S. invasion of Iraq and offensive against Ansar al-Islam in 2003 renamed the organization Ansar al-Sunna in September 2003. {{"Ansar al-Islam." Australian Parliament, 20 March 2009. Web. 5 February 2010.}}

NameChange.name: Ansar al-Islam
NameChange.description: In 2007, AI’s Shariah Council split from the larger organization and founded Ansar al-Sunna Shariah. In order to distance itself from Ansar al-Sunna Shariah, which was adamantly opposed to AQI, AI officially changed its name back to Ansar al-Islam. {{“Background Information on Ansar al-Islam.” Parliament of Australia, Date unknown. Web. 19 Aug 2015.}}

Size.citation: Taylor, Catherine. "Taliban Style Group Grows in Iraq." Christian Science Monitor, 15 March 2002. Web. 5 February 2010.
Taylor, Catherine. "Taliban Style Group Grows in Iraq." Christian Science Monitor, 15 March 2002. Web. 5 February 2010.
"Ansar al-Islam." Australian Parliament, 20 March 2009. Web. 5 February 2010.

Size.size: Although its precise size was unknown, AI was cons
Size.citation: “Country Reports on Terrorism 2014-Foreign Terrorist Organizations: Ansar al-Islam.” United States Department of State, June 2015. Web. 24 Aug 2015.

Group.name: Ansar al-Sunna Shariah
Group.description: Ansar al-Sunna Sharia (AS Shariah) is an Iraqi nationalist organization that calls upon all sectors of the Iraqi public to support the end of foreign occupation in Iraq and implement Sharia Law in the nation. The group is speculated to have split from Ansar al-Islam in 2007 over objections to Al Qaeda in Iraqs's targeted killings of civilians. AS Shariah is a member of both the Jihad and Reform Front and the Political Council of Iraqi Resistance.

Attack.description: A video of an attack claimed by AS Shariah shows an IED hitting an American supply truck.
Attack.source: "LiveLeak.com - IED Hitting an American Supply Truck." LiveLeak.com - IED Hitting an American Supply Truck. Web. 24 July 2015.

Attack.description: A video claimed that an AS Shariah sniped and killed an American solider in Northern Baghdad.
Attack.source: "LiveLeak.com - Sniper Shoots an American Soldier in N. Baghdad." LiveLeak.com - Sniper Shoots an American Soldier in N. Baghdad. Web. 27 July 2015.

Attack.description: A video of an attack claimed by AS Shariah depicts supposed members of the group blowing up an American Humvee with an IED.
Attack.source: "LiveLeak.com - Shariah Committee of Ansar Al Sunnah: Huge IED Attack on Humvee." LiveLeak.com - Shariah Committee of Ansar Al Sunnah: Huge IED Attack on Humvee. Web. 24 July 2015.

Leader.name: Abu Sajjad
Leader.description: In 2007, Sajjad left AI and aligned with the Islamic Army of Iraq (IAI) and the Mujahideen Army (MA) to form the Jihad and Reform Front (RJF).
Leader.source: "Shariah Committee of Ansar al-Sunna Army: A 'Book of Truth or an Imaginary Fantasy." Statement published by the Shariah Committee of Ansar al-Sunna. August 5, 2008. Retrieved from http://www.nefafoundation.org/miscellaneous/nefaansarsunnah0808.pdf

Leader.name: Shaykh Abu Hind
Leader.description: In 2007, Hind left AI and aligned with the Islamic Army of Iraq (IAI) and the Mujahideen Army (MA) to form the Jihad and Reform Front (RJF).
Leader.source: "Shariah Committee of Ansar al-Sunna Army: A 'Book of Truth or an Imaginary Fantasy." Statement published by the Shariah Committee of Ansar al-Sunna. August 5, 2008. Retrieved from http://www.nefafoundation.org/miscellaneous/nefaansarsunnah0808.pdf

Group.name: Islamic Army in Iraq
Group.description: The Islamic Army in Iraq (IAI) is a Sunni Islamist militant organization created in 2003 with the aim of expelling foreign troops from Iraq. From 2003-2011, the group primarily targeted U.S. forces in Iraq, although in 2006 and 2007, several clashes between IAI and Al Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) fighters were reported. The group dissolved itself in 2011 following the U.S. withdrawal in Iraq and its members subsequently created a political activism group called Sunni Popular Movement. The IAI re-activated in December 2013 to fight against the Maliki government alongside many other Sunni insurgent groups. Although it has worked with the Islamic State (IS) since its resurgence in 2013, an IAI spokesman indicated that the partnership is one of convenience and that it may soon dissolve.

Attack.description: The IAI took two French journalists hostage in the area between Baghdad and Najaf, demanding that the French parliament lift its ban on Islamic headscarves in public schools. The two journalists were released unharmed in December 2004.
Attack.source:
Karacs, Imre. "French Hostages Held Over Scarf Ban," Sunday Times, LexisNexis Academic, 29 August 2004, p. 23.

Buel, Meredith. "Deadly Attack on US Military Base Near Mosul Kills 24." Voice of America, December 2004. Web. 29 May 2010.

Attack.description: The IAI claimed responsibility for a vehicle-borne improvised explosive device (VBIED) that detonated at a city entrance checkpoint in Ar Ramadi, Anbar, killing 11 Iraqi police commandos and wounding 3 Iraqi civilians and 2 U.S. Marines.
Attack.source: "Reports on Incidents of Terrorism 2005." NCTC, 11 April 2006, p. 42.

Attack.description: Ansar al-Sunnah, the Mujahideen Army, and the IAI claimed responsibility for two simultaneous vehicle-borne improvised explosive device (VBIED) attacks in different areas of Bagdad in which seven civilians and three police officers were killed and ten other civilians wounded.
Attack.source: "Reports on Incidents of Terrorism 2005." NCTC, 11 April 2006, p. 42.

Attack.description: The IAI claimed responsibility for shooting down a commercial helicopter north of Baghdad.
Attack.source: "Reports on Incidents of Terrorism 2005." NCTC, 11 April 2006.

Attack.description: The IAI killed 18 AQI militants when it attacked an AQI-held compound near the city of Samarra. During the attack, 15 IAI fighters were also killed and 16 AQI fighters were captured.
Attack.source: "Statement from the Islamic Army of Iraq." NEFA Foundation, 2 April 2008. Web. 1 June 2010.

Attack.description: The IAI claimed responsibility for an IED attack at a gas station in the Karradah district of Baghdad.
Attack.source: “200901050005.” Global Terrorism Database, START, Date Unknown. Web. 10 Aug 2015.

Attack.description: The Islamic Army of Iraq claimed that it and the Mujahideen Army had coordinated an attack on government forces near al-Karma. The groups purportedly downed a government helicopter during the fighting.
Attack.source: Jawad al-Tamimi, Aymenn. “Interview with the leader of Iraq’s Jaysh al-Mujahideen: Abd al-Hakim al-Nuaimi.” 17 March 2014. Web. 22 July 2015.

Attack.description: The IAI kidnapped U.S. security contractor Ronald Alan Schulz, demanding that all Iraqi prisoners held by the U.S. be released. When the U.S. failed to meet its demands, the IAI released a video of Schulz’s execution.
Attack.source: “US Hostage Killed, Iraq Militant Group Says.” NBC News, 8 Dec. 2005. Web. 10 Aug. 2015.

Attack.description: Al Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) militants attacked and killed 30 IAI fighters after they refused to pledge allegiance to AQI.
Attack.source: Ridolfo, Kathleen. "Iraq: Al-Qaeda Tactics Lead To Splits Among Insurgents." Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, 17 April 2007. Web. 30 May 2010.

Attack.description: Al Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) militants attacked and killed 30 IAI fighters after they refused to pledge allegiance to AQI.
Attack.source: Ridolfo, Kathleen. "Iraq: Al-Qaeda Tactics Lead To Splits Among Insurgents." Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, 17 April 2007. Web. 30 May 2010.

Attack.description: Al Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) militants attacked and killed 30 IAI fighters after they refused to pledge allegiance to AQI.
Attack.source: Ridolfo, Kathleen. "Iraq: Al-Qaeda Tactics Lead To Splits Among Insurgents." Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, 17 April 2007. Web. 30 May 2010.

Attack.description: The IAI fought along side the Islamic State (IS) when it captured Mosul from the Iraqi army on June 10, 2014.
Attack.source: Sherlock, Ruth & Malouf, Cerol. “Islamic Army of Iraq founder: Isis and Sunni Islamists will march on Baghdad.” The Telegraph, 20 June 2014. Web. 5 August 2015.

Leader.name: Ishmael Jubouri
Leader.description: Jubouri is a leader of Islamic Army in Iraq; however, little is known about his specific role in the group. He is a Sunni tribal member in central Iraq, and has supported increasing the frequency of the group’s attacks.
Leader.source: Spinner, Jack. "Marines Widen Their Net South of Baghdad." The Washington Post, 27 November 2004. Web. 3 August 2012.

Leader.name: Sheikh Ahmed al-Dabash
Leader.description: Dabash is one of the founding leaders of the IAI and currently acts as the group’s spokesman when dealing with the international media. He was on the U.S.’s Most Wanted list in Iraq for much of the late 2000s.
Leader.source: Sherlock, Ruth & Malouf, Cerol. “Islamic Army of Iraq founder: Isis and Sunni Islamists will march on Baghdad.” The Telegraph, 20 June 2014. Web. 5 August 2015.

Size.citation: "Armed Groups within Iraq." The Globe and Mail, 13 July 2007, p. A10.

Size.size: Believed to be the largest armed group in Iraq
Size.citation: "Iraq Tribal Leader Offers US Talks." Al Jazeera, 13 September 2007. Web. 26 June 2010

Group.name: Mujahideen Army
Group.description: The Mujahideen Army (MA) is a Sunni Iraqi militant organization that first gained international attention in late 2004. The group is vehemently anti-American and seeks to overthrow the Iraqi government, which it views as an American and Iranian puppet. The group was briefly a member of the Reformation and Jihad Front with Ansar al-Sunnah Sharia and the Islamic Army in Iraq from 2007 to 2008 and has been adamant in it opposition to IS since 2014.

Attack.description: The Mujahideen Army took an American, a Nepali, a Filipino, and two Iraqis hostage. All were released except the American, who was rescued by U.S. troops seven months later.
Attack.source: "Mujahideen Army." National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism, 1 March 2008. Web. 28 January 2010.

Attack.description: The Mujahideen Army claimed responsibility for shooting down an American helicopter in Baghdad with a missile. Confrontations with armed men were reported in the area following the crash.
Attack.source: "Iraq's Mujahidin Army said claiming downing of US chopper." Al-Jazeera TV, 27 June 2005.

Attack.description: The Mujahideen Army claimed credit for downing an American Apache helicopter north of Baghdad.
Attack.source: "Dual claim on copter crash." The Daily Telegraph, LexisNexis, 17 January 2006.

Attack.description: The Mujahideen Army claimed responsibility for shooting down an American Black Hawk helicopter outside of Baghdad.
Attack.source: Young, Fiona. "13 die as chopper downed." LexisNexis Academic, Sunday Mail, 21 January 2007.

Attack.description: The Mujahideen Army claimed credit for killing an American soldier in northern Baghdad.
Attack.source: "Iraqi al-Mujahidin Army claims credit killing of US soldier in Baghdad." LexisNexis Academic, Al-Jazeera satellite news, 27 May 2009.

Attack.description: he MA allegedly bombed a U.S. intelligence vehicle north of Baghdad.
Attack.source: "Insurgent group claims attack on US vehicle in Iraq." LexisNexis Academic, Al Jazeera TV, 29 August 2009.

Attack.description: The MA launched a series of mortar attacks in the Green Zone in Baghdad.
Attack.source: "Biden Meets With Iraqi Officials, a Day After Mortar Attack." Voice of America News, 16 September 2009. Web. 27 February 2010.

Attack.description: The Islamic Army of Iraq claimed that it and the Mujahideen Army had coordinated an attack on government forces near al-Karma. The groups purportedly downed a government helicopter during the fighting.
Attack.source: Jawad al-Tamimi, Aymenn. “Interview with the leader of Iraq’s Jaysh al-Mujahideen: Abd al-Hakim al-Nuaimi.” 17 March 2014. Web. 22 July 2015.

Attack.description: The MA took ten Iraqis hostage and eventually executed eight of the ten. All of the hostages worked for an contracting firm with American ties.
Attack.source: "Mujahideen Army." National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism, 1 March 2008. Web. 28 January 2010.

Leader.name: Abd al-Hakim al-Nuaimi
Leader.description: Nuaimi is believed to be the leader of the Mujahideen Army.
Leader.source: Jawad al-Tamimi, Aymenn. “Interview with the leader of Iraq’s Jaysh al-Mujahideen: Abd al-Hakim al-Nuaimi.” 17 March 2014. Web. 22 July 2015.

Leader.name: Haqi Ismael al-Shortani
Leader.description: Shortani is believed to be in charge of all of the military operations of the Mujahideen Army.
Leader.source: Adnan, Sinan & Reese, Aaron. “Middle East Security Report 24: Beyond the Islamic State: Iraq’s Sunni Insurgency.” Understanding War, October 2014. Web. 23 July 2015.

Leader.name: Ahmad Ni'mah Khudayyir Abbas
Leader.description: Ahmad Ni'mah Khudayyir Abbas, more commonly known as Abu Shihab, was the group’s propaganda chief and was in charge of overseeing all of the MA’s IED and mortar attacks. He was captured by U.S. troops in the Abu Ghraib district to the west of Bagdad in October 2005.
Leader.source: "Jaysh al-Mujahideen terrorist lieutenant and propaganda chief captured.” GlobalSecurity.org, 23 October 2005. Web. 2 February 2010.

Group.name: Hamas Iraq
Group.description: Hamas Iraq is an Iraqi Sunni Islamist organization that broke away from the 1920s Revolution Brigades in March 2007. The group primarily targeted U.S. forces in Iraq from 2007-2011. In July 2007, Hamas Iraq joined with several of Iraq’s largest insurgent groups to form an umbrella organization called the Political Council for Iraqi Resistance (PCIR).

Attack.description: Al Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) and the 1920s Revolution Brigades accused Hamas Iraq of fighting alongside the US against AQI in Diyala. Hamas Iraq repudiated these claims.
Attack.source:
“Terrorist Rehabilitation: The U.S. Experience in Iraq.” CRC Press: 2012.

Ali, Abdallah Suleiman. “ISIS prefers allegiance, not allies, in Iraq.” Al Monitor, 17 June 2014. Web. 10 Aug. 2015.

Attack.description: Hamas Iraq claimed responsibility for a rocket attack on a U.S. military vehicle in Anbar.
Attack.source: "Hamas-Iraq claims blowing up US vehicle with homemade rocket," LexisNexis Academic, Al-Jazeera (Qatar) via BBC Monitoring Middle East, 22 January 2008.

Attack.description: Hamas Iraq used two improvised explosive devices (IEDs) against an American army hummer and utility vehicle in Diyala and subsequently posted a video of the attack online.
Attack.source: “Hamas Iraq: Two IED’s against Hummer and utilitary vehicle in Diyala.” Liveleak, 27 August 2007. Web. 10 Aug 2015.2007-08-27

Attack.description: Hamas Iraq orchestrated several grenade attacks against American forces in Baqouba in the Diyala province.
Attack.source: Tomkins, Richard. "Ba'athist comeback feared; Insurgent former Saddam loyalists seen causing violence." LexisNexis Academic, The Washington Times, 4 June 2009.

Leader.name: Harith Dhahir Khamis al-Dari
Leader.description: Dari was the leader of the 1920s Revolution Brigades before he was assassinated by Al Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) operatives on March 27, 2007. After his death, Hamas Iraq split from the 1920s RB to form an independent group.
Leader.source: Khalil, Lydia. “Leader of the 1920 Revolution Brigades Killed by al-Qaeda.” Jamestown Foundation, 10 April 2007. Web. 10 Aug. 2015.

Group.name: 1920s Revolution Brigades
Group.description: Founded in 2003, the 1920s Revolution Brigades (1920s RB) is a nationalist, Sunni organization whose main goal is to free Iraq of foreign occupation, particularly from American military and political presence. Once Iraq is free of outside influence, the 1920s RB aims to install an Iraqi government guided by Sunni Islamist principles. Today, the organization maintains a strong stance against IS. However, the Political Office of the 1920s RB opposed the participation of Arab States in the coalition against IS because the coalition conducted air strikes on the Sunni areas of Iraq in 2014.

Attack.description: The 1920s RB, as part of the Anbar Salvation Council, fought AQI in the Anbar Provence.
Attack.source: Roggio, Bill, "1920s Revolution Brigades turns on al Qaeda in Diyala," The Long War Journal, June 12, 2007, retrieved on July 12, 2010.

Attack.description: The 1920s Revolution Brigade kidnapped and held U.S. Marine, Wassef Ali Hassoun for three weeks in June 2004. The organization threatened to kill Hassoun in a video shown on Al Arabiya television. It is unclear if Hassoun worked with the group to stage the kidnapping to avoid desertion charges. He was found at the Beirut embassy on July 7th, and was charged for desertion by the Navy in 2004.
Attack.source: Sink, Mindy, "Marine Who Was Missing in Iraq Is Charged With Deserting Post," New York Times, 10 December 10, 2004, retrieved on July 12, 2010.

Attack.description: The group fought AQI in the Diyala province in their first attack following the split from Hamas Iraq. The city of Buhriz in Diyala was a stronghold of AQI’s power, but the 1920s RB drove the group of out of the city in this attack.
Attack.source: "1920s Revolution Brigades Turns on Al Qaeda in Diyala." The Long War Journal. 12 June 2007. Web. 22 June 2015.

Attack.description: The 1920s RB shot down an American drone in Kirkuk.
Attack.source: "1920 brigades claims credit for downing US drone in Kirkuk," Al-Jazeera TV, August 16, 2008, LexisNexis Academic.

Attack.description: The 1920s RB claimed responsibility for bombing an American military vehicle in northern Iraq.
Attack.source: "1920 Brigades attack on US vehicle in Iraq," Al-Jazeera TV, June 21, 2009, LexisNexis Academic.

Attack.description: The 1920s RB bombed an American military vehicle in Western Baghdad.
Attack.source: "Iraqi Insurgent Group Claims Attack on US Military Vehicle," Al Jazeera via BBC Monitoring Middle East, December 22, 2009, LexisNexis Academic.

Leader.name: Hatim al-Zawbai
Leader.description: Zawbai was reported to be commander of the 1920s Revolution Brigades by the Iraqi Defense Ministry when he was captured in January 2005. It is unclear how long he had been in command.
Leader.source: "National Guard arrests 217, militia commander in Al-Mahmudiyah," GlobalSecurity.org, January 2, 2005, retrieved on July 12, 2010.

Leader.name: Unknown
Leader.description: The Iraqi government reported the capture and arrest of a senior officer of the 1920s RB in 2006. The leader’s identity remains unknown
Leader.source: The Iraqi government reported the capture and arrest of a senior officer of the 1920s RB in 2006. The leader’s identity remains unknown Roggio, Bill, "Commander of 1920 Revolution Brigades Captured," The Long War Journal, September 24, 2006, retrieved on

Leader.name: Aswad Kamil Al-Falahi
Leader.description: A senior commander of the 1920s RB, Al-Falahi was killed by an AQI suicide attack in Habbaniyah in February 2007.
Leader.source: Roggio, Bill, "The Amiriya Battle," The Long War Journal, March 2, 2007, retrieved on July 12, 2010.

Leader.name: Ahmed Sabah
Leader.description: A senior commander of the 1920s RB, Sabah was killed in an AQI suicide attack in Habbaniyah in February 2007.
Leader.source: Roggio, Bill, "The Amiriya Battle," The Long War Journal, March 2, 2007, retrieved on July 12, 2010.

Leader.name: Harith al-Dari
Leader.description: Dari was killed by a car bomb in a mass attack on the city of Talafar in March 2007.
Leader.source: Khalil, Lydia. “Leader of the 1920 Revolution Brigades Killed by al-Qaeda.” Jamestown Foundation, 10 April 2007. Web. 10 Aug. 2015.

Leader.name: Sheik Ahmed al-Tamer
Leader.description: al-Tamer was killed by a suicide bomb in Diyala province in September 2007. He had been attending a peace meeting between the United Jihad Factions Council, the Madhi Army, and a Sunni coalition militia.
Leader.source: Tawfeeq, Mohammed, "24 die in Iraq peace meeting blast," CNN, September 25, 2007, retrieved on July 29, 2010.

Leader.name: Naim al-Dulaimi
Leader.description: A local, high-ranking leader of the 1920s RB, al-Dulaimi was killed by a female suicide bomber outside Baquba in July 2008.
Leader.source: Sterling, Joe, et al., "100 female U.S. service members have died in Iraq," CNN, 24 July 2008, retrieved on July 12, 2010.

Leader.name: Unknown
Leader.description: The current leader of the 1920s RB is unknown.

Size.citation: Tyson, Ann Scott, "Sunni Fighters Find Strategic Benefits in Tentative Alliance With U.S.," The Washington Post, 9 August 2007, retrieved on April 24, 2010.

Group.name: Jaysh Rijal al-Tariqa al-Naqshbandia (JRTN)
Group.description: The Jaysh Rijal al-Tariq al-Naqshbandia (JRTN) is a Sufi insurgent group largely comprised of ex-Baath Party members. It was formed by Izzat Ibrihim al-Douri in 2006 in response to the execution of Saddam Hussein. With Hussein’s death, many of Iraq’s remaining Baathists coalesced around Douri, the most senior remaining Ba’athist leader in the country, forming the basis of the JRTN. The group has since expanded to become one of the most powerful insurgent organizations in Iraq, second only to the Islamic State (IS). Despite their almost diametrically opposed ideologies, the JRTN and IS have worked closely with one another on multiple occasions, most notably in the capture of Mosul in June of 2014.

Attack.description: Hamas Iraq troops used Rocket Propelled Grenades to attack US forces in Baqouba, the provincial capital of Diyala. It was not until the Hamas Iraq cell was apprehended that the U.S. discovered that the cell had been subcontracted by the JRTN, which was responsible for planning, financing, and facilitating the attack.
Attack.source: "Ba'athists aiding insurgent attacks." The Washington Post, 4 June 2009. Web. 30 June 2015.

Attack.description: A child recruited by JRNT threw an RKG-3, an anti-vehicle grenade, at a passing US convoy in the Kirkuk province. The attack was taped and circulated on the Internet.
Attack.source: Naylor, Justin. "Child Recruited by Terrorists Kills Five Police in Kirkuk." emilitary.org, 14 May 2009. Web. 14 July 2015.

Attack.description: The JRTN claimed responsibility shooting and killing a US soldier in the city of Tikrit in Iraq's Salah ad Din province.
Attack.source: "Suspected JRTN militant kills US solider in Iraq's Salah ad Din." Jane's Terrorism and Insurgency Centre, 1 September 2010. Web. 15 July 2015.

Attack.description: The JRTN made a statement on Al Jazeera claiming responsibility for attacking a US soldier in Baghdad on an unspecified date. However, the claim could not be independently verified.
Attack.source: "JRTN claims attack on US solider in Iraq's Baghdad." Jane's Terrorism and Insurgency Centre, 5 October 2010. Web. 15 July 2015.

Attack.description: Senior commander of JRNT accused of being involved in an IED attack in a car showroom in the town of Muqdadiyah.
Attack.source: "Security forces detain alleged senior JRTN commander in Iraq's Diyala." Jane's Terrorism and Insurgency Centre, 22 February 2011.

Attack.description: The JRTN played a critical role in IS’s capture of Mosul and was responsible for seizing control of the five bridges that connect the western and eastern sections of the city.
Attack.source: Wood, Shree. “Jaysh al-Tariqa al-Naqshbandia.” Next Century Foundation, Date unknown. Web. 26 June 2015.

Attack.description: JRTN soldiers clashed with IS fighters in the city of Hawija near Kirkuk. Reports differ as to whether the skirmish occurred because there was disagreement over which group would assume control of several captured oil tankers or because the JRTN fighters refused to lay down their weapons and swear fealty to al-Baghdadi.
Attack.source: Jawad al-Tamini, Aymenn. “Enemy of My Enemy: Re-evaluating the Islamic State’s relationship with Ba’athist JRTN.” June 2015.

Attack.description: The JRTN used a RKG-3 to target an Iraqi Army convey west of Mosul.
Attack.source: Allum, Paul. “Sunni militant group, Jaysh Rijal al-Tariqa al-Naqshbandia, evolve in northern Iraq.” International Operations, 23 Jan. 2013. Web. 26 June 16.

Attack.description: According to the JRTN’s official website, the group was responsible for launching several rockets into the city of Hawija near Kirkuk.
Attack.source: Qiyada. “Statement by the Men of the Naqshbandi Army on the process of rocket fire into the city of Hawija.” The Website of the Men of the Naqshbandi Army. (L. Newby, Trans.) 6 June 2015. Web. 22 June 2015. < http://www.alnakshabandia.net/army/>

Leader.name: Izzat Ibrahim al-Duri
Leader.description: Following Saddam Hussein’s execution in December of 2006, Douri became the de facto leader of the remaining Ba’athists in Iraq and founded the JRTN. On April 17, 2015, Iraqi state-run television reported that Douri had been killed by Iraqi security forces and Shiite militia fighters in the mountains between Kirkuk and Tikrit. The report was corroborated by the Governor of the Salah al-Din province, in which the alleged assassination took place. Photos were released of what appears to be Douri’s corpse. However, the JRTN repudiated these claims and in May 2015 released an audio clip of Douri in which he addressed events that occurred after his purported death.
Leader.source: Knights, Michael. “Saddam Hussein’s Faithful Friend, the King of Clubs, Might Be the Key to Saving Iraq.” New Republic, 24 June 2014. Web. 25 June 2015.

Leader.name: Abd al Majid Hadithi
Leader.description: Hadithi was the JRTN’s media manager and propaganda distributor before being arrested by Iraqi and US forces in Tikrit Iraq in December 12, 2009.
Leader.source: “Northern Iraq ERB arrests multiple JRTN terror cell members," Official Website of the United States Force-Iraq, 13 December 2009. Web. 2 July 2015.

Leader.name: Azhar al-Obeidi
Leader.description: Obeidi is a former Ba’athist army general who holds a leadership position in the JRTN. After the fall of Mosul on June 10, 2014, IS named Obeidi as the governor of Mosul as a show of friendship to their JRTN allies. Obeidi is no longer the governor of Mosul but his current whereabouts are unknown.
Leader.source: Harris, Shane. “The Re-Baathification of Iraq.” Foreign Policy, 21 August 2014. Web. 30 June 2014.

Size.source: The Combating Terrorism Center at West Point
Size.citation: Knights, Michael. “The JRTN Movement and Iraq’s Next Insurgency.” The Combating Terrorism Center at West Point, 1 July 2011. Web. 27 June 2015.

Group.name: The Islamic State
Group.description: The Islamic State (IS) also known as the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS) and The Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant (ISIL) is a Salafi militant organization whose goal is the establishment and expansion of a caliphate. IS has its origins in the early 2000s, when Abu Musab al-Zarqawi began training extremist militants. Zarqawi’s militants became a major participant in the Iraqi insurgency during the American occupation, first under the name Jama’at al-Tawhid wa’al-Jihad and then, after swearing fealty to Al Qaeda, as Al Qaeda in Iraq. Facing backlash from the community and increased security from U.S. and Iraqi forces, the group faced decline until 2011, when it began to grow through its involvement in the Syrian Civil War. In 2013, it changed its name to the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS). Over the course of 2013 and 2014, it quickly took over territory in Syria and Iraq. In addition to its rapid expansion, ISIS has also drawn attention for its public beheadings of Western captives and its large contingent of foreign fighters. On the ground, IS has fought Syrian government forces, Syrian rebel groups, the Iraqi military and militias, and the Kurdish peshmerga. The U.S. began airstrikes against the group in fall 2014.

Attack.description: JTJ assassinated Laurence Foley in Jordan
Attack.source: "Jamaat al-Tawhid wa'l-Jihad," GlobalSecurity.org, 6 Dec. 2006. Web. 26 Jan. 2010.

Attack.description: ISIS attacked Baji oil field, although the Iraq Army reported that it successfully drove out ISIS within two to three days of fighting
Attack.source: Rubin, Alissa J. and Suadad Al-Salhy. “Iraq Officials Claim Control of Major Refinery in Baji.” The New York Times. The New York Times, 19 Jun. 2014. Web. 26 Jun. 2014.

Attack.description: JTJ bombed the UN Headquarters in Baghdad, killing prominent UN diplomat Sergio Vieira de Mello and twenty-two others
Attack.source: "Truck bomb kills chief U.N. envoy to Iraq," CNN.com, August 20, 2003, retrieved on February 4, 2010 ; "19 arrested in Najaf shrine blast," USA Today. August 31, 2003, retrieved on February 4, 2

Attack.description: The group bombed the Imam Ali Shrine in Najaf
Attack.source: "19 arrested in Najaf shrine blast," USA Today. USA Today, 31 Aug. 2003. Web. 4 Feb. 2010.

Attack.description: Zarqawi beheaded American civilian worker Nicholas Berg in Iraq
Attack.source: Jehl, Douglas, "CIA thinks Zarqawi killed Berg," The New York Times, May 14, 2004, p. 5, LexisNexis Academic.

Attack.description: The group bombed western hotels in Amman, Jordan
Attack.source: Thomas, Gordon, "Terrorist chiefs in bitter power split: Secret note over deaths of Muslims sparks three killer blasts," Sunday Express, November 13, 2005, p. 43, LexisNexis Academic.

Attack.description: The organization bombed the Shi'ite Golden Mosque in Samarra, 65 miles north of Baghdad, sparking retaliation against 100 or more Sunni mosques
Attack.source: Knickmeyer, Ellen and K.I. Ibrahim, "Bombing shatters mosque in Iraq: Attack on Shiite shrine sets off protests, violence." The Washington Post. The Washington Post, 23 Feb. 2006. Web. 4 Feb. 2010.

Attack.description: SIS beheaded American captive James Foley and releases a video of the murder. The video garnered international attention and ISIS would proceed to behead more British and American hostages in the coming months
Attack.source: Yourish, Karen. "The Fates of 23 ISIS Hostages in Syria." The New York Times. The New York Times, 23 Oct. 2014. Web. 9 Jan. 2015.

Attack.description: AQI claimed responsibility for the bombings of several government buildings in Baghdad
Attack.source: Londoño, Ernesto, "Al-Qaeda in Iraq gaining in strength," Washington Post Foreign Service, 22 Nov. 2009. Web. 26 Jan. 2010.

Attack.description: AQI carried out attacks across Iraq in response to the killings of AQI leaders Masri and Baghdadi
Attack.source: "Al-Qaeda in Iraq Blamed For Attacks." Al-Jazeera. Al-Jazeera, 11 May. 2010. Web. 16 May. 2010.

Attack.description: ISIS took control of an air defense base in Hama, Syria
Attack.source: Roggio, Bill. “Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant overruns air defense base in Hama.” The Long war Journal. Foundation for Defense of Democracies, 14 Sep. 2013. Web. 23 Jun. 2014.

Attack.description: AQI attacked Abu Ghraib and Taji prisons in Iraq, freeing approximately 800 prisoners with Al Qaeda affiliations
Attack.source: Al Arabiya. “Iraq gunmen launch deadly attack on Abu Gharib and Taji prisons.” Al Arabiya. Al Arabiya, 22 Jul. 2013. Web. 25 Jun. 2014.

Attack.description: AQI claimed responsibility for attacks across eight cities in just under six hours. Shiites, police, security forces and government officials were targeted in Karbala, Kirkuk, and Baghdad
Attack.source: "Al Qaeda claims responsibility for Iraq attacks" Associated Press. 21 Mar. 2012.Web. 21 Mar. 2012.

Attack.description: ISIS takes control of Raqqa, Syria
Attack.source: BBC. “Profile: Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant (ISIS). BBC. BBC, 6 Jun. 2014. Web. 23 Jun. 2014.

Attack.description: ISIS took control of Mosul
Attack.source: Al-Salhy, Suadad and Tim Arango. “Sunni Militants Drive Iraq Army Out of Mosul.” The New York Times. The New York Times, 10 Jun. 2014. Web. 26 Jun. 2014.

Attack.description: Eleven members of the Islamic State killed 130 civilians and injured 100 more in a series of attacks in Paris, France. Gunman and suicide bombers attacked a concert hall, a soccer stadium, restaurants, and bars in the French capital. Within the days following the attack, nine of the IS operatives were killed. One operative remained on the run until he was captured in Brussels on March 18, 2016. According to French President Hollandaise, the attacks were planned in Syria organized in Belgium
Attack.source: "Paris Attacks: Salah Abdeslam 'refused to Blow Himself Up' - BBC News." BBC News. Web. "Paris Attacks: Islamic State Group 'releases Video of Attackers' - BBC News." BBC News. Web. 28 Feb. 2016. "Paris Attacks: What Happened on the Night - BBC Ne

Attack.description: ISIS seized border crossings at Qaim, Waleed, and Trebil, gaining control over the border between Iraq and Syria and the border between Iraq and Jordan
Attack.source: Arango, Tim and Michael R. Gordon. “Iraqi Insurgents Secure Control of Border Posts.” The New York Times. The New York Times, 23 Jun. 2014. Web. 25 Jun. 2014.

Attack.description: Over a period of two weeks, ISIS executed 700 members of the al-Sheitaat tribe in the Deir al-Zor province, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights. The tribe and ISIS began fighting in July
Attack.source: Holmes, Oliver, and Suleiman Al-Khalidi. "Islamic State Executed 700 People from Syrian Tribe: Monitoring Group." Reuters. Thomson Reuters, 16 Aug. 2014. Web. 6 Nov. 2014.

Attack.description: ISIS publicly executed a number of members of a Sunni tribe, the Albu Nimr, that had been resisting ISIS’s advance in the Anbar province. Reports on the number of dead range from forty-six to over three hundred, and differ on whether or not women and children were killed along with men
Attack.source: Stout, David. "ISIS Massacres Sunni Tribe in Iraq." Time. 4 Nov. 2014. Web. 6 Nov. 2014. Morris, Loveday, and Mustafa Salim. "Islamic State Publicly Kills at Least 46 Sunni Oppo

Attack.description: ISIS began to carry out its first assaults on U.S. bases in Iraq, conducting mortar attacks against a training base. According to senior U.S. defense officials, the attacks have been completely ineffective against the base
Attack.source: Miklaszewski, Jim, and Oliver Cox. "ISIS Attacks on U.S. Military 'Ineffective,' Officials Say." NBC News. NBC, 6 Jan. 2015. Web. 23 Jan. 2015.

Attack.description: ISIS seized Ramadi, the capital of Anbar province, from Iraqi security forces, which were supported by Shiite militias and American airstrikes. ISIS had controlled areas around Ramadi for almost a year and a half before taking the city
Attack.source: Arango, Tim. "Key Iraqi City Falls to ISIS as Last of Security Forces Flee." The New York Times. N.p., 17 May 2015. Web. 18 May 2015.

Attack.description: Five IS militants attacked a Starbucks and a police station in Jakarta, Indonesia, armed with suicide explosives and handguns. One Canadian civilian, one Indonesian civilian, and five attackers were killed
Attack.source: Cochrane, Joe, and Thomas Fuller. "Jakarta Attack Raises Fears of ISIS’ Spread in Southeast Asia." The New York Times. The New York Times, 2016. Web. "Indonesia: ISIS's New Battlefront." Time. Time. Web.

Attack.description: Members of the Islamic State set off three nail bombs in Brussels, Belgium: two bombs were detonated in the Brussels Airport and one in the Maalbek Metro Station. In the two days following the attack, European authorities arrested eleven Islamic State militants that have been linked to this attack and the November 2015 attack in Paris, France
Attack.source: Graham-Harrison, Emma, Arthur Neslen, and Patrick Greenfield. "Brussels Attacks: Last Gasp of Isis Terror in Europe, or Sign of Growing Threat?" The Guardian. Guardian News and Media, 2016. Web. 04 Apr. 2016. "Three More Arrested in Brussels Police

Leader.name: Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi
Leader.description: Baghdadi, also known as Abu Du’a, took control of AQI in 2010 and led its expansion. He is a secretive figure, not appearing in video until a July 2014 sermon, and little is known about him.
Leader.source: "Profile: Abu Bakr Al-Baghdadi." BBC News. N.p., 5 Jul. 2014. Web. 16 Dec. 2014. Hunt, Emily, "Zarqawi's 'Total War' on Iraqi Shiites exposes a divide among Sunni Jihadists," The Washington Institute for Near East Policy, 15 Nov. 2005. 26 Jan. 2010.

Leader.name: Abu Umar al-Baghdadi
Leader.description: Masri’s replacement as top commander, Baghdadi was killed in a joint U.S.-Iraqi raid in 2010. Some sources reported that Baghdadi was not actually the true leader of AQI, but instead a figurehead meant to give the organization an Iraqi face to combat local backlash concerning its foreign origins and membership.
Leader.source: Kirdar, MJ. AQAM Futures Project Case Studies Series: Al Qaede in Iraq. Publication. Center for Strategic and International Studies, Jun. 2011. Web. 24 Nov. 2014. Kirdar, MJ. AQAM Futures Project Case Studies Series: Al Qaede in Iraq. Publication. Center

Leader.name: Abu Ayub al-Masri
Leader.description: Masri, also known as Hamza al-Muhajir and Abu Hamza, became AQI's top commander after Zarqawi's death. A former member of the Egyptian Islamic Jihad (EIJ), Masri had close ties to AQ leadership, particularly EIJ leader Ayman al-Zawahiri. Masri was killed during a joint raid by U.S. and Iraqi solders in April 2010, several years after officially turning over power to Abu Umar al-Baghdadi. Some reports indicated that Masri maintained control after Baghdadi became the face of the organization.
Leader.source: Kirdar, MJ. AQAM Futures Project Case Studies Series: Al Qaede in Iraq. Publication. Center for Strategic and International Studies, June 2011. Web. 24 Nov. 2014. Kirdar, MJ. AQAM Futures Project Case Studies Series: Al Qaede in Iraq. Publication. Center

Leader.name: Abu Mus'ab al-Zarqawi
Leader.description: AQI's founder and first leader, Zarqawi was killed in a U.S. airstrike in 2006. He was a major figurehead in the Iraqi insurgency and became America’s most wanted man in Iraq.
Leader.source: Knickmeyer, Ellen, and Jonathan Finer. "Insurgent Leader Al-Zarqawi Killed in Iraq." Washington Post. N.p., 08 June 2006. Web. 18 Dec. 2014.

NameChange.name: Jama'at Tawhid wal Jihad (JTJ)
NameChange.description: Zarqawi’s most prominent force in Iraq, which the U.S. State Department used to refer to Zarqawi’s network of militants.

NameChange.name: Al Qaeda in Iraq (AQI; Tanzim Qaidat al-Jihad fi Bilad al-Rafidayn in Arabic)
Islamic State in Iraq (ISI)
NameChange.description: A rebranding attempt, intended to consolidate support, stress the focus on governmental infrastructure, and gain a wider base of followers. It also continued to be known as AQI.

NameChange.name: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS) or Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant (ISIL)
NameChange.description: The group’s cooperation with AQ Central and al-Nusra broke down, while its operations expanded into Syria. It is sometimes translated as “the Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant” (ISIL). The variation in translation stems from the word al-Sham, which refers to an area spanning Southern Turkey through Syria to Egypt, which can be translated as “Greater Syria” or “the Levant.”

NameChange.name: Islamic State (IS)
NameChange.description: The group declared a Caliphate under Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi. Many media sources continue to refer to the group as ISIS/ISIL.

Size.citation: "Country Reports on Terrorism," United States Department of State, Office of the Coordinator for Counterterrorism, Apr. 2006. Web. 4 Feb. 2010.
Tilghman, Andrew, "The myth of AQI," Washington Monthly, Oct. 2007. Web. 26 Jan. 2010.
"Country Reports on Terrorism 2011." U.S. Department of State. Published July 31, 2012.
Zahiyeh, Ehab. “How ISIL became a major force with only a few thousand fighters.” 19 Jun. 2014. 23 Jun. 2014.
The Economist. “The Islamic State of Iraq and Greater Syria: Two Arab countries fall apart.” The Economist, 13 Jun. 2014. Web. 23 Jun. 2014.
Yeginsu, Ceylan. "ISIS Draws a Steady Stream of Recruits From Turkey." The New York Times. 15 Sept. 2014. Web. 11 Nov. 2014.

Size.source: U.S. Military via Council of Foreign Relations
Size.citation: Zenko, Micah. "How Many Bombs Did the United States Drop in 2015?" Council on Foreign Relations. Council on Foreign Relations, 2016. Web. 28 Feb. 2016.

Group.name: Al Qaeda
Group.description: Al Qaeda is one of the most powerful terrorist organizations in the world, with a long history and a global reach. It is composed of a core group of operatives and leadership, largely based in Pakistan and Afghanistan, and also maintains relationships with a number of global affiliate organizations. AQ and its affiliates have been responsible for many of the deadliest terrorist attacks in the past twenty-five years.

Attack.description: Two gunmen attacked the offices of the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo in Paris. The paper had previously been targeted by Islamic extremists for its satire of Islam, and was listed in an AQ “most wanted” list. AQAP claimed the attack, and there is evidence that at least one of the gunmen traveled to Yemen, participated in AQ training, and receiving funding for an attack.
Attack.source: {{Schmitt, Eric, Mark Mazzetti, and Rukmini Callimachi. "Disputed Claims Over Qaeda Role in Paris Attacks." The New York Times. N.p., 14 Jan. 2015. Web. 03 Aug. 2015. .}}

Attack.description: Two truck bombs detonated outside the U.S. embassies in Dar Es Salaam, Tanzania and Nairobi, Kenya. The significant majority of casualties occurred in Nairobi. The bombings took place on the 8th anniversary of U.S. troops' presence in Saudi Arabia. Al Qaeda and the Egyptian Islamic Jihad claimed responsibility.
Attack.source: {{"U.S. Embassy Bombings". U.S. Department of State. Published August 5, 2007. http://www.state.gov/www/regions/africa/kenya_tanzania.html. Accessed July 27, 2012.}}

Attack.description: An AQAP suicide bomber drove a small watercraft towards the side of the hull of the U.S.S. Cole naval ship, detonating a large bomb stored on the watercraft upon impact.
Attack.source: {{"A Claim for the Cole." CBS News. June 21, 2001. http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2001/06/20/world/main297600.shtml. Accessed July 27, 2012.}}

Attack.description: In the most destructive attack ever attributed to Al Qaeda, operatives hijacked four jetliners and piloted two into the World Trade Center towers and one into the Pentagon building. The fourth plane crashed in Pennsylvania, probably en route to an additional target. It was the first major foreign attack on American soil since Pearl Harbor, the most violent day in America’s history after the battle of Antietam in 1862, and resulted in economic damages valued at between $100 billion and $2 trillion. Following the attacks, the United States invaded Afghanistan to find and prosecute those responsible for the attacks, causing bin Laden and his organization to flee for remote regions of Afghanistan and Pakistan.
Attack.source: {{"Bin Laden claims responsibility for 9/11." CBS News. October 29, 2004. http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/story/2004/10/29/binladen_message041029.html. Accessed July 27, 2012.}} {{Riedel, Bruce O. The Search for Al Qaeda: Its Leadership, Ideology, and Future

Attack.description: A truck bomb exploded at the Marriot Hotel in Islamabad. Intelligence officials suspected AQ, although the attack was never claimed.
Attack.source: {{Gall, Carlotta. "Bombing at Hotel in Pakistan Kills at Least 40." The New York Times, 20 Sept. 2008. Web. 31 July 2015. .}}

Attack.description: AQAP made the first attempted attack against the U.S. homeland by an AQ affiliate when Umar Farouk Abdul Mutallab failed to set off an explosive device on a plane.
Attack.source: {{McGrath, Kevin. Confronting Al Qaeda: New Strategies to Combat Terrorism. Annapolis, MD: Naval Institute, 2011. Print. 68.}}

Attack.description: Al Qaeda in Iraq detonated a series of car bombs and carried out mortar attacks in Sadr City, Iraq. It was the deadliest sectarian attack since the beginning of the War in Iraq in 2003.
Attack.source: {{"Baghdad curfew after bombing wave." BBC News. November 24, 2006. http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/6178994.stm. Accessed July 27, 2012.}}

Attack.description: Four British men detonated 3 bombs on the London Underground and one on a double-decker bus during morning rush hour in London. Al Qaeda claimed the bombings, but there is no direct evidence that shows that AQ directed the attack.
Attack.source: {{Report of the Official Account of the Bombings in London on 7th July 2005. Rep. House of Commons, 11 May 2006. Web. 31 July 2015. .}}

Attack.description: Seventeen members of the self-proclaimed "Jerusalem Squadron", attacked two oil industry buildings in Khobar, Saudi Arabia. The militants took 41 hostages, reportedly questioning and releasing only Muslim hostages prior to their standoff with police. Abdulaziz al-Muqrin, the leader of AQAP from 2003-2004, claimed responsibility for the attacks in an audio tape.
Attack.source: {{Bakier, Abdul Hameen. "Lessons from al Qaeda's attack on the Khobar compound." August 11, 2006. The Jamestown Foundation. http://www.jamestown.org/programs/gta/single/?tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=871&tx_ttnews%5BbackPid%5D=181&no_cache=1. Accessed July 27, 2

Attack.description: Over two days (11/15 and 11/20, 2003), four truck bombs ran into 2 Jewish synagogues, a bank, and the British Consulate in Istanbul, Turkey. The bombing at the British Consulate may have been coordinated with U.S. President Bush's meeting with Tony Blair, which occurred the day of the second bombing (11/20/2003).
Attack.source: {{"Bin Laden alledgedly planned attack in Turkey." Associated Press. MSNBC News. http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/3735645/#.UBLxkkL-DzI. December 17, 2003.}}

Attack.description: After coordinated bombs went off on Madrid’s public transportation system, killing 191, a Spanish government investigation report found that AQ may have inspired the attacks, but that AQ had no involvement in the planning or operation of the bombings. Intelligence gathered after the investigation suggests that AQ may have facilitated and supervised the attack.
Attack.source: {{Nash, Elizabeth. "Madrid Bombers 'were Inspired by Bin Laden Address'" The Independent. N.p., 7 Nov. 2006. Web. 04 Aug. 2015. .}} {{Reinares, F

Leader.name: Atiyah abd al-Rahman
Leader.description: Rahman, an AQ operative from Libya who was close with bin Laden, took over as AQ’s operational planner after bin Laden’s death, effectively serving at the organization’s second-in-command. He was killed by a U.S. drone strike in August 2011.
Leader.source: {{Mazzetti, Mark. "C.I.A. Drone Is Said to Kill Al Qaeda’s No. 2." The New York Times. N.p., 27 Aug. 2011. Web. 15 July 2015.}} {{Hoffman, Bruce. "Al Qaeda's Uncertain Future." Studies in Conflict & Terrorism 36.8 (2013): 636. Web. 15 July 2015. }}

Leader.name: Osama bin Laden
Leader.description: Bin Laden was the Saudi-born founder and leader of Al Qaeda. He supported the Afghan resistance to the Soviet occupation in the 1980s, then began to target the U.S. and other Western influences with Al Qaeda. He was killed by U.S. Navy Seals in May 2011.
Leader.source: {{Zernike, Kate, and Michael T. Kaufman. "The Most Wanted Face of Terrorism." The New York Times, 01 May 2011. Web. 15 July 2015.}}

Leader.name: Ayman al-Zawahiri
Leader.description: Zawhiri was AQ’s longtime second-in-command who became the group’s leader in 2011 when bin Laden was killed. Some analysts credit Zawahiri with controlling the group’s strategy before bin Laden’s death, while bin Laden acted as AQ’s figurehead. Others call Zawahiri, who comes from a family of politicians and religious scholars, AQ’s ideological mastermind.
Leader.source: {{Cragin, R. Kim. "A Recent History Of Al-Qa'ida." The Historical Journal. J. 57.03 (2014): 804. Web. 18 July 2015.}} {{Riedel, Bruce O. The Search for Al Qaeda: Its Leadership, Ideology, and Future. Washington, D.C.: Brookings Institution, 2008. 17. Pri

Leader.name: Mustafa Abu al-Yazid, also known as Sheikh Saeed al-Masri
Leader.description: Yazid was a founder and financial chief of AQ, and also was believed to be third in command of the group behind Zawahiri and bin Laden. He played a vital role in operational planning, especially attacks on Western forces in Afghanistan. Yazid was killed in May 2010 by a U.S. drone strike.
Leader.source: {{Schmitt, Eric. "American Strike Is Said to Kill a Top Qaeda Leader." The New York Times. 31 May 2010. Web. 15 July 2015.}}

Leader.name: Abu Yahya al-Libi
Leader.description: Libi was a Libyan Islamic scholar who played large role in AQ operations. He was reportedly second to Zawahiri when he was killed in a U.S drone strike in North Waziristan.
Leader.source: {{Walsh, Declan, and Eric Schmitt. "Drone Strike Killed No. 2 in Al Qaeda, U.S. Officials Say." The New York Times. 05 June 2012. Web. 15 July 2015.}}

Leader.name: Nasser al-Wuhayshi
Leader.description: Wuhayshi was the leader of AQAP and reportedly became the second-in-command of Al Qaeda soon before his death in June 2015, when he was killed by a U.S. drone strike.
Leader.source: {{Shane, Scott. "No. 2 Qaeda Leader May Have Died in U.S. Airstrike in Yemen." The New York Times. 15 June 2015. Web. 15 July 2015.}}

Size.citation: {{Silverstein, Ken. "The Al Qaeda Clubhouse: Members Lacking." Harper's Magazine. July 5, 2006. http://www.harpers.org/archive/2006/07/sb-al-qaeda-new-members-badly-needed-1151963690. Accessed August 2, 2012.}}

{{Silverstein, Ken. "The Al Qaeda Clubhouse: Members Lacking." Harper's Magazine. July 5, 2006. http://www.harpers.org/archive/2006/07/sb-al-qaeda-new-members-badly-needed-1151963690. Accessed August 2, 2012.}}

Size.source: London International Institute of Strategic Studies
Size.citation: {{McGrath, Kevin. Confronting Al Qaeda: New Strategies to Combat Terrorism. Annapolis, MD: Naval Institute, 2011. Print. 65.}}

{{Bialik, Carl. "Shadowy Figures: Al Qaeda's Ranks are Hard to Measure." The Wall Street Journal. September 9, 2011. http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424053111903285704576560593124523206.html. Accessed July 30, 2015.}}

Group.name: Hezbollah
Group.description: Hezbollah is a Shiite political and militant organization based in Lebanon. Since its creation in the 1980s, it has evolved into a hybrid organization woven into the structure of Lebanese society through social services and active participation in politics while also carrying out international terrorist attacks and regional military operations. The group regularly clashes with Israel and opposes Western influence in Lebanon, and most recently has been involved in the Syrian Civil War as an ally of the Assad government.

Attack.description: Hezbollah took over parts of Beirut after government calls to disarm, resulting in street violence and over 60 deaths. The resulting negotiations with the government gave Hezbollah veto power in the national cabinet
Attack.source: United States. U.S. Department of State. Bureau of Counterterrorism. Country Report on Terrorism 2009. N.p., 5 Aug. 2010. Web. 27 June 2014.

Attack.description: Hezbollah collaborated with and led the Syrian Army in their attack on al-Qusayr, a rebel stronghold, playing a significant role in the conflict for the first time after months of rumored involvement in the Syrian Civil War. Hezbollah and the Syrian Army were victorious, marking a turning point in the war in which Assad began to regain key strategic territory

Hezbollah’s international wing bombed an Israeli tour bus in Bulgaria, killing five Israelis and the Bulgarian bus driver. This was the first successful attack in a campaign to increase global operations beginning around 2008. Hezbollah denies responsibility for the bombing
Attack.source: Levitt, Matthew. "Hizb Allah Resurrected: The Party of God's Return to Tradecraft." Combating Terrorism Center at West Point. 29 Apr. 2013. Web. 14 Feb. 2015.

Attack.description: Hezbollah kidnapped two Israeli soldiers and killed 8 more, sparking a month-long war with Israel
Attack.source: "Terrorist Organization Profile: Hezbollah." University of Maryland, n.d. Web. 26 June 2014.

Attack.description: In 2011, the UN Special Tribunal for Lebanon indicted four members of Hezbollah for the February 2005 car bomb assassination of former Lebanese Prime Minister Rafiq al-Hariri that also killed 21 others
Attack.source: "UN Tribunal Releases Hariri Indictment." Al Jazeera English. 17 Aug. 2011. Web. 9 Apr. 2015. Bergman, Ronen. "The Hezbollah Connection." The New York Times. 14 Feb. 2015. Web. 10 Apr. 2015.

Attack.description: Hezbollah bombed the American Khobar Towers housing complex in Saudi Arabia, killing 19
Attack.source: Leonnig, Carol D. "Iran Held Liable In Khobar Attack." Washington Post. N.p., 23 Dec. 2006. Web. 27 June 2014. "Incident 199606250006." Global Terrorism Database

Attack.description: Hezbollah was implicated in the bombing of the Argentine-Israeli Mutual Association, which killed 85 people and wounded more than 200. It denied responsibility
Attack.source: United States. U.S. Department of State. Patterns of Global Terrorism: 1994. N.p., Apr. 1995. Web. 27 June 2014. Barrionuevo, Alexei. "Inquiry on 1994 Blast at Argentina Jewish Center Gets New Life."

Attack.description: Hezbollah member Ahmad Qasir carried out a truck bombing against an Israeli headquarters in Tyre, killing at least 75 Israelis and fourteen Arab prisoners.
Attack.source: Norton, Augustus R. Hezbollah: A Short History. Princeton: Princeton UP, 2007. 80 Print.

Attack.description: A suicide bombing on the U.S. Embassy in Beirut killed 63 people and was attributed to militants of the Islamic Jihad, an early alias of Hezbollah
Attack.source:
"Terrorist Attacks against Americans, 1979-1988." Frontline: Target America. PBS, n.d. Web. 26 June 2014.
"Incident 198304180001." Global Terrorism Database. University of Maryland

Attack.description: Hezbollah members highjacked TWA flight 847, holding hostages for weeks and killing one before releasing the rest in exchange for the release of 300 Lebanese prisoners in Israel
Attack.source: "Terrorist Organization Profile: Hezbollah." University of Maryland, n.d. Web. 26 June 2014. Pearson, Erica. The Sage Encyclopedia of Terrorism. Ed. Gus Martin. Second ed. T

Attack.description: Hezbollah members hijacked TWA flight 847, holding hostages for weeks and killing one before ultimately releasing the rest in exchange for the release of 300 Lebanese prisoners in Israel
Attack.source:
"Terrorist Organization Profile: Hezbollah." University of Maryland, n.d. Web. 26 June 2014. 
Pearson, Erica. The Sage Encyclopedia of Terrorism. Ed. Gus Martin. Second ed. T

Attack.description: Hezbollah operatives carried out a truck bombing of the Israeli Embassy in Buenos Aires, killing twenty-nine and wounding 242
Attack.source: United States. U.S. Department of State. Patterns of Global Terrorism: 1992. N.p., n.d. Web. 27 June 2014.

Attack.description: Hezbollah collaborated with and led the Syrian Army in their attack on al-Qusayr, a rebel stronghold, playing a significant role in the conflict for the first time after months of rumored involvement in the Syrian Civil War. Hezbollah and the Syrian Army were victorious, marking a turning point in the war in which Assad began to regain key strategic territory
Attack.source: Blanford, Nicholas. "The Battle for Qusayr: How the Syrian Regime and Hizb Allah Tipped the Balance." CTC Sentinel 6.8 (2013): 18-22. Combatting Terrorism Center at West Point. Web. 25 June 2014.

Attack.description: Hezbollah fired anti-tank missiles at Israeli soldiers in the disputed Har Dov area between Lebanon and Syria, killing two. In a separate border incident on the same day between Israel and Hezbollah, a UN Interim Force member was killed
Attack.source: Levs, Josh. "2 Israeli Soldiers, Peacekeeper Killed in Israel-Hezbollah Fighting - CNN.com." CNN. 28 Jan. 2015. Web. 30 Jan. 2015.

Attack.description: For the final two weeks of May 2015, Hezbollah forces were engaged in heavy fighting against Jabhat al-Nusra (Al-Nusra) and IS across the Qalamoun mountain range in western Syria. By early June Hezbollah had recaptured much of the mountain range and reopened a path from Lebanon into Syria
Attack.source: Samaha, Nour. “Hezbollah Is ‘Stronger Than Ever.’” Foreign Policy, 1 June 2015. Web. 20 April 2016.

Attack.description: Hezbollah and Syrian government forces clashed with rebel troops belonging to Al-Nusra, Ahrar al-Sham and the Free Syrian Army near the village of Tal al-Ais outside of Aleppo. The village overlooks the main road connecting Aleppo to Damascus and is thus of strategic importance to both sides. Eight Hezbollah troops were killed in addition to 25 pro-Assad forces and 18 rebels
Attack.source: “Eight Hezbollah fighters killed in Aleppo clashes over weekend.” The Daily Star Lebanon, 4 April 2016. Web. 20 April 2016.

Leader.name: Sayyad Abbas Musawi
Leader.description: Musawi was Hezbollah’s cofounder and first secretary-general. He was killed in 1992 by an Israeli helicopter strike that also killed at least six others.
Leader.source: Haberman, Clyde. "Israelis Kill Chief of Pro-Iranian Shiites in South Lebanon." New York Times. N.p., 17 Feb. 1992. Web. 25 June 2014.

Leader.name: Hassan Nasrallah
Leader.description: Nasrallah is Hezbollah’s current secretary-general. Under his leadership, Hezbollah continued military operations and increased its role in politics.
Leader.source: "Profile: Hassan Nasrallah." Backgrounders. Council on Foreign Relations, 11 Aug. 2010. Web. 27 June 2014.

Leader.name: Imad Mughniyeh
Leader.description: Mughniyeh was Hezbollah’s senior military commander and was reportedly responsible for a number of overseas attacks. He was killed in a car bombing in 2008 that was allegedly carried out by Mossad in coordination with the CIA.
Leader.source:
Bakri, Nada, and Graham Bowley. "Top Hezbollah Commander Killed in Syria." New York Times. New York Times, 13 Feb. 2008. Web. 26 June 2014.
